contextId.occurrenceNote: Their "hearts" represent their thoughts. Often such thoughts could come unintentionally, without the person wanting to think them. Alternate translation: "cursed God in their thoughts" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: cursed God in their hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" refers to God's power to act. "But now use your power" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: But now stretch out your hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "touch" represents the action of harming or destroying. Alternate translation: "attack all that he has" or "destroy all that he has" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: touch all that he has

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" represents someone's power to control something. Alternate translation: "you have power over all that he has" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: all that he has is in your hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here striking represents killing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: have struck

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Skin" here is a metonym for Job's life. Alternate translation: "A person will do anything to save his own life, even accept the loss of possessions and loved ones" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Skin for skin, indeed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" refers to God's power to act. "But now use your power." See how you translated this in [Job 1:11](../01/11.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: stretch out your hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "touch" represents the action of harming. Alternate translation: "attack" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: touch

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "lips" represents the act of speaking. Alternate translation: "sin by speaking against God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: sin with his lips

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "eyes" represents the person who sees with them. Alternate translation: "from me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: from my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "voice" is a metonym for the power that the slave drivers have over the slaves. Alternate translation: "They are no longer under the control of the slave drivers" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the voice of the slave driver

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the grave represents death. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the grave

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "weak hands" represents people who need help. Alternate translation: "you have helped others when they needed help" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: you have strengthened weak hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word  "hand" represents power or control. Alternate translation: "having my adversary control me ... having my oppressors control me" or "my adversary's power ... my oppressors' power" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: my adversary's hand ... the hand of my oppressors

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Job's speech is represented by his "tongue." Alternate translation: "in my speech" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: on my tongue

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "his place" represent those who live in his place. Alternate translation: "the people who live in his place" or "his family" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: his place

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the mouth represents speech. Alternate translation: "I will not restrain my speech" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will not restrain my mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "bed" and "couch" are metonyms for "sleep." In lying down to sleep, Job would hope to be comforted. The metonyms also have human attributes; they have the ability to comfort and ease a person. Alternate translation: "My bed, my couch, will be like someone who can comfort me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: My bed will comfort me, and my couch will ease my complaint

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the mind represents thoughts and attention. To "set your mind on" means to give attention to. Alternate translation: "direct your attention to him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: set your mind on him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "lie down in the dust" is a metonym that represents dying. Alternate translation: "now I will die" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: now will I lie down in the dust

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" represents the power or results of sin. Bildad implies that God killed Job's children because of their sin. Alternate translation: "for God caused the consequences of your children's sins to kill them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: for he gave them into the hand of their sins

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hearts" represents their inner beliefs. Alternate translation: "that they sincerely believe" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: from their hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "the paths" represents a person's future and the events that will happen to them. Alternate translation: "The same thing will happen to everyone who forgets God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: So also are the paths of all who forget God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "take the hand" refers to help or support. Alternate translation: "God will not support people who do evil things" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: neither will he take the hand of evildoers

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the heart represents the inner being or thoughts. Alternate translation: "wise in what he decides" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: wise in heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "mouth" represents Job's words. Alternate translation: "my own words would accuse me" or "what I say would condemn me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: my own mouth would condemn me

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "despair" is an abstract noun that can be translated by the verb "despair." Here it is a metonym for the innocent who are despairing. Alternate translation: "the innocent who are despairing" or "the innocent who have lost all hope" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the despair of the innocent

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "the earth" is used to represent the people on the earth. Alternate translation: "The people of the world are" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: The earth is

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" is a metonym for "control." Alternate translation: "into the control of" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: into the hand of

contextId.occurrenceNote: "come together to trial." Here "court" is a place where people can come and a judge will settle disputes. "Coming together in court" is a metonym for going against each other in a court of law. Alternate translation: "confront each other before a judge" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: come together in court

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "God's rod" is a metonym for God punishing or correcting Job. Alternate translation: "stop God from punishing me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: take God's rod off me

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "open his lips" are a metonym that means speak. These two phrases mean the same thing and are used together to emphasize Zophar's desire that God would speak harshly against Job. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: that God would speak ... open his lips against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hand represents what a person does. Alternate translation: "even if you had done some evil things in the past" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: suppose that iniquity were in your hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Lifting up your face" represents the attitude of a person who is confident and brave. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: lift up your face without a sign of shame

contextId.occurrenceNote: Their tents prospering represents the robbers prospering in their tents. Alternate translation: "Robbers live in prosperity in their own tents" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: The tents of robbers prosper

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "their own hands" is a metonym for strength, and "their gods" is a metaphor for their pride. Alternate translation: "they are extremely proud of their own abilities" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: their own hands are their gods

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh's hand represents his power. Alternate translation: "Yahweh has done this by his power" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the hand of Yahweh has done this

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh's hand represents his control or power. Alternate translation: "God controls the life of every living thing and gives breath to all mankind" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: In his hand is the life ... and the breath of all mankind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "breath" represents life or the ability to live. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the breath of all mankind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are that 1) this is a metonym for causing kings to no longer have authority. Alternate translation: "He takes away the authority of kings" or 2) this is a metonym for setting people free from the chains that kings have put on them. Alternate translation: "He takes off the bonds that kings have put on people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: He takes off the chain of authority from kings

contextId.occurrenceNote: This cloth is probably what a slave wears. To put these cloths on kings represents making the kings slaves. Alternate translation: "he makes kings wear the clothing of slaves" or "he makes them slaves" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: he wraps a cloth about their waists

contextId.occurrenceNote: Removing their speech represents making them unable to speak. Alternate translation: "He makes those who were trusted unable to speak" or "He silences people whom others trusted" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: He removes the speech of those who had been trusted

contextId.occurrenceNote: Taking away their understanding represents making them unable to understand or make good decisions. Alternate translation: "makes the elders unable to understand" or "makes the elders unable to make good decisions" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: takes away the understanding of the elders

contextId.occurrenceNote: God leading nations represents God causing enemy nations to lead them. The word "them" represents nations, which here represents the people of those nations. Alternate translation: "he also causes their enemies to lead them along as prisoners" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: he also leads them along as prisoners

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Flesh" here is a metonym for life. "Teeth" and "hands" are metonyms for his own control. These two phrases together emphasize that Job is willing to risk his life by arguing his case with God. Alternate translation: "I am ready to risk my life" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: I will take my own flesh ... in my hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: An oppressive hand is a metonym for doing things that oppress someone. Withdrawing the hand is a metaphor for stopping doing those things. Alternate translation: "stop oppressing me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: withdraw your oppressive hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "your terrors" refers to what causes people to be terrified of God. Alternate translation: "do not terrify me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: do not let your terrors make me afraid

contextId.occurrenceNote: The number of man's months being with God represents God deciding the number of months that the man will live. "You decide how many months he will live" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: The number of his months is with you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here God's hands represent him making things. Job refers to himself as the work of God's hands. Alternate translation: "for me, whom you have made" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.glQuote: for the work of your hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Footsteps represent his life or what he does. Alternate translation: "my life" or "the things I do" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: my footsteps

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the way a crafty man speaks as his "tongue." Alternate translation: "to speak in the way of a crafty man" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: to have the tongue of a crafty man

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "heart" represents a person's emotions. Alternate translation: "Why do your emotions take you away?" or "Why do you allow your emotions to guide your decisions?" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Why does your heart carry you away?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "the sword" is a metonym that represents an enemy who is waiting to kill the evil man. Possible meanings are 1) he is worried that someone will murder him. Alternate translation: "he worries that someone is about to murder him" or 2) it is certain that he is going to be murdered. Alternate translation: "someone is waiting to murder him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: the sword waits for him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Darkness here represents death. Alternate translation: "out of the darkness of death" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: out of darkness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here God's "breath" represents his judgement. Alternate translation: "God's breath" or "God's judgment" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the breath of God's mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "mouth" and "lips" are metonyms for the words or messages that a person speaks using his mouth and lips. Here Job is speaking sarcastically and means the opposite of what he says. Alternate translation: "My words would surely not be encouraging to you! They would surely not lighten your grief" or "By speaking to you as you spoke to me earlier, I would not encourage you or lighten your grief!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.glQuote: I would strengthen you with my mouth, and the quivering of my lips will bring you relief!

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Job's "mouth" represents what he says. Alternate translation: "with what I say" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: with my mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for the words or message that he speaks. Alternate translation: "my comforting words" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the quivering of my lips

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here a person's "hands" refer to his "control." Alternate translation: "delivers me to the control" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: throws me into the hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Hands" refers to a person's ability and activity. Alternate translation: "I have not acted violently" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: there is no violence in my hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of himself dying as if he would be murdered. Here his "blood" is a metonym referring to his death. Alternate translation: "Earth, when I die, do not hide how I died unfairly" or "Let it not be hidden how I died unfairly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Earth, do not cover up my blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of his vision as his "eyes." Alternate translation: "My vision has become weak because I am so sad" or "I am almost blind because of my sorrow" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: My eye is also dim because of sorrow

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Job's "heart" represents his inner being. Alternate translation: "my plans will never happen, nor will the things that I have desired most" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: my plans are shattered, and so are the desires of my heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Regarding, looking, is a metonym here for thinking well or badly of someone. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: regarded

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "light" refers to life, and the word "darkness" refers to death. Alternate translation: "from the light of life to the darkness of death" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: from light into darkness

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "my mouth" is a metonym which refers to Job speaking. Alternate translation: "even though I speak to him and plead with him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: although I entreat him with my mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "breath" represents the smell of his breath. If something is offensive to someone, it means that he hates it. Alternate translation: "My wife hates the smell of my breath" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: My breath is offensive to my wife

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "touched me" is a metonym for "hit me." And, "hand" represents God's power. Causing Job to suffer is spoken of as if Yahweh were physically hitting him with his hand. Alternate translation: "because God has afflicted me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: for the hand of God has touched me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to standing to speak in court. Possible meanings are 1) the Redeemer will be the last one to speak in the court. Alternate translation: "he will judge whether or not I am guilty" or 2) the Redeemer will stand in this final court to defend Job. Alternate translation: "at last he will defend me in court" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: at last he will stand on the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: His flesh represents his body, and "in my flesh" represents being alive. Alternate translation: "while I live in my body, I will see God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: in my flesh I will see God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are that the sword represents 1) God judging them. Alternate translation: "then be afraid that God will judge you" or 2) God killing them. Alternate translation: "then be afraid that God will kill you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: then be afraid of the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "his place" represents those who live in his place. Alternate translation: "the people who live in his place" or "his family" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: his place

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hands" refers to the wicked man's children. When he dies, his children will have to return everything that he took from others. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: his hands will have to give back his wealth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "it" refers to his youthful strength. The metonym "lie down ... in the dust" represents dying. The strength dying is a metaphor for disappearing. Alternate translation: "but his youthful strength will die with him" or "but his youthful strength will disappear when he dies" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: but it will lie down with him in the dust

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "cast them out of his stomach" is a metonym for causing the man to vomit them. This is a metaphor for causing the man to lose his riches. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: God will cast them out of his stomach

contextId.occurrenceNote: The viper is a poisonous snake. Its tongue represents its poisonous bite. Alternate translation: "the viper's poisonous bite will kill him" or "the viper will bite him and he will die" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the viper's tongue will kill him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" represents power, and "hand ... will come against him" represents people attacking him. The abstract noun "poverty" can be expressed with the adjective "poor." Alternate translation: "everyone who is in poverty will attack him" or "everyone who is poor will attack him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: the hand of everyone who is in poverty will come against him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "fill his stomach" is a metonym meaning eat a lot. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: to fill his stomach

contextId.occurrenceNote: The iron weapon represents the person carrying it. Alternate translation: "will flee from the person carrying an iron weapon" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: will flee from the iron weapon

contextId.occurrenceNote: The bow represents the person who shoots an arrow with it. Alternate translation: "someone with a bronze bow will shoot him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: a bow of bronze will shoot him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are: 1) those who live in the heavens and the earth or 2) Zophar is describing the heavens and the earth as if they are humans who will testify in court against the wicked person. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: The heavens ... the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "wrath" represents punishment. The abstract noun "wrath" can be expressed with the verb punish. Alternate translation: "the day when God punishes people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the day of God's wrath

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "houses" refers to the family members that lives in them. Alternate translation: "Their families" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Their houses

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to God's punishment. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: rod of God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hands" refers to their power or control. Job uses this question to challenge his friends. Alternate translation: "Look, these wicked people claim that they make themselves prosper!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: See, is not their prosperity in their own hands?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "arms" refer to power. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "you even oppressed orphans" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: the arms of the fatherless have been broken

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "from his mouth" represents what God has spoken. Alternate translation: "the instruction that God has spoken" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: instruction from his mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "heart" refers to Job's thoughts. Alternate translation: "your mind" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: your heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) "I can barely lift my hand because of my groaning" or 2) "God's hand continues to make me suffer in spite of my groaning" where "hand" refers to God's power to punish. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: my hand ... heavy because of my groaning

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "fill my mouth" refers to speaking. Alternate translation: "I would speak all of my arguments" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: fill my mouth with arguments

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase refers to the message that God spoke. Alternate translation: "that he spoke" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: of his lips

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is another way of referring to a person. Alternate translation: "a person" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: a son of man

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job's "life" being bitter represents Job feeling resentful toward God. Alternate translation: "has caused me to become resentful" or "has made me feel angry because of the unfair way he has treated me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: made my life bitter

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Breath ... in my nostrils" represents being able to breathe. "Breath from God" represents God making him able to breathe. Alternate translation: "God enables me to breathe" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the breath from God is in my nostrils

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the phrase "my thoughts" represents Job. Alternate translation: "even in my thoughts, I will not reproach myself" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: my thoughts will not reproach me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hear his cry" represents responding to the godless man's cry and helping him. Alternate translation: "Will God respond to his cry" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Will God hear his cry

contextId.occurrenceNote: God's "hand" represents his power. Alternate translation: "the power of God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the hand of God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "the sword" represents dying in battle. Alternate translation: "they will die in battle" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: it is for the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "be buried" represents dying. Alternate translation: "will die by plague" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: will be buried by plague

contextId.occurrenceNote: Opening his eyes represents waking up in the morning. Alternate translation: "he wakes up" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: he opens his eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sets an end to darkness" represents shining a light in the darkness. People used a lantern or a torch for light. Alternate translation: "A man carries light into dark places" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: A man sets an end to darkness

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents breaking up the rock. Alternate translation: "digs into the flinty rock" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: lays his hand on the flinty rock

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents them having so much respect for Job that they had nothing to say. Alternate translation: "they felt that they were unable to speak" or "they had nothing to say" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: their tongue clung to the roof of their mouths

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sat" represents ruling or leading. Chiefs sat down when they made important decisions. Alternate translation: "led them as their chief" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: sat as their chief

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job was their chief. Alternate translation: "led them because I was their chief" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: sat as their chief

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are that 1) "dry ground" is a metonym for the dry roots that grow in the ground. Alternate translation: "they chewed on the dry roots they found in the ground" or 2) "gnawed at the dried ground" is a metonym for eating whatever they could find in the dry ground. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: they gnawed at the dry ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated in active form. Possible meanings are 1) the idea of whips implies that they were being treated like criminals. Alternate translation: "People treated them like criminals and forced them to leave the land" or 2) people actually used whips to force them out. Alternate translation: "People whipped them and forced them to leave the land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: They were driven out of the land with whips

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "byword" is a metonym for the person about whom people make cruel jokes. Alternate translation: "I am now one whom they make cruel jokes about" or "They joke and say cruel things about me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I have become a byword for them

contextId.occurrenceNote: "the rabble rise upon my right hand." Possible meanings are 1) rising upon Job's right hand represents attacking his strength. Alternate translation: "Gangs of young people attack my strength" or 2) rising upon Job's right hand represents attacking his honor. Alternate translation: "Mobs attack my honor" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Upon my right hand rise the rabble

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of God using his force as if God's force were actually doing something. Here "God's ... force" stands for "God." Alternate translation: "God has seized my clothing by his great force" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: God's great force has seized my clothing

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "hand" represents God's power. Alternate translation: "you persecute me with your power" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: with the strength of your hand you persecute me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "my harp" represents Job himself, and also represents his desire to sing only songs of mourning. Alternate translation: "I play only songs of mourning on my harp" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: my harp is tuned for songs of mourning

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "my flute" represents Job himself, and also his desire to sing only songs of crying. Alternate translation: "I play only songs of wailing on my flute" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: my flute for the singing of those who wail

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "my heart" and "my eyes" are metonyms for what Job desires and sees. The heart going after the eyes is a metaphor for desiring to do what he sees. It is implied that this refers to sinful things that Job sees. Alternate translation: "if I have have wanted to do any sinful things that I see" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: if my heart has gone after my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "it" here refers to the action sleeping with another man's wife. This action is a metonym for the punishment that Job would suffer as a result of the action. A fire burning up his harvest is a synecdoche for losing everything he has worked for. Alternate translation: "those who punish me would take away everything I have worked for" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: it would burn all my harvest to the root

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "the wool of my sheep" represents blankets or clothing made from the wool of Job's sheep. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "because the wool of my sheep has not warmed him" or "because I have not given him clothing made from the wool of my sheep" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: because he has not been warmed with the wool of my sheep

contextId.occurrenceNote: Lifting up the hand against someone represents threatening to harm him. Alternate translation: "if I have threatened to harm fatherless people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: if I have lifted up my hand against fatherless people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "my hand" represents Job's ability to do things. Alternate translation: "I have gained many possessions by my own ability" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: my hand had gotten many possessions

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "asking for his life with a curse" represents cursing someone's life so that he will die. Alternate translation: "by cursing him so that he would die" or "by cursing his life" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: by asking for his life with a curse

contextId.occurrenceNote: The tent represents Job's household. The men of his tent includes family members and servants. All of these knew Job well. Alternate translation: "the men of my household" or "my family members and servants" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the men of my tent

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job is explaining how he truly treated foreigners. Here "stay in the city square" represents sleeping overnight in the city square. Alternate translation: "foreigners have never had to sleep in the city square" or "foreigners have never had to sleep outside" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: even the foreigner has never had to stay in the city square

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "opened my doors to the traveler" represents welcoming the traveler into his home. Alternate translation: "I have always welcomed the traveler into my home" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I have always opened my doors to the traveler

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents dying. Alternate translation: "to die" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: to lose their lives

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines mean the same thing. Elihu emphasizes that since older people are wiser than younger people, they should be the first to speak of what they know. Alternate translation: "He who has lived many years should speak; He would is older should teach wisdom" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Length of days should speak; a multitude of years should teach wisdom

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the spirit is represented by "breath." Alternate translation: "the spirit of the Almighty" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the breath of the Almighty

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words refer to where he goes. Here where he goes represents what he does. Alternate translation: "everything that I do" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: my paths

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "death" represents the place where people go when they die, that is, sheol. Alternate translation: "from going to sheol" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: from crossing over to death

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the person is represented by his "life." Also, living is spoken of as seeing the light. Alternate translation: "I will continue to live and see the daylight" or "I will continue to live" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my life will continue to see light

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hands" refer to power. Alternate translation: "for God made them all" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: for they all are the work of his hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: God's "eyes" represent his sight. The phrase "a person's ways" is an idiom for what he does and how he lives. Alternate translation: "For God watches everything a person does" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: For God's eyes are upon a person's ways

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here to "see" means to know. Alternate translation: "teach me what I have done wrong that I am not aware of" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: teach me what I cannot see

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here punishing the person because of his sin is referred to as punishing the "person's sin." Alternate translation: "that person because of his sin" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: that person's sin

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "arms" refers to power or strength. Alternate translation: "they call for someone to deliver them from the power of mighty men" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: they call for help from the arms of mighty men

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "his anger" is a metonym for "him." Alternate translation: "he never punishes anyone because he is angry" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: his anger does not punish

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "heart" refers to the thoughts and emotions. The phrase may indicate that the person stubbornly refuses to trust God. Alternate translation: "who refuse to trust in God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: who are godless in heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "minds" represents the person's thoughts. Alternate translation: "those who are wise in their own thinking" or "those who consider themselves to be wise" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: those who are wise in their own minds

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) their labor pains are over when the birth is finished or 2) "labor pains" is a metonym that refers to the offspring of the goats and deer because they are the result of the mother's labor and pain. Alternate translation: "send out their offspring from their womb" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: then they finish their labor pains

contextId.occurrenceNote: The horse's "mane" is spoken of as if it was clothing for the neck of the horse. Alternate translation: "made his flowing main to cover his neck like clothes" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: clothe his neck with his flowing mane

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "the weapons" represent the battle in which they are used. Alternate translation: "to join in the battle" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: to meet the weapons

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the stretching out of his wings refers to flying. Alternate translation: "flies to the south" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: stretches out his wings for the south

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job's self is a metonym for what he said. Alternate translation: "I despise the things I said" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: despise myself

contextId.occurrenceNote: The person is a metonym for the prayer he prays. Alternate translation: "God accepted Job's prayer for his three friends" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh accepted Job
